first so the views and comments I
expressed today are mine and mine alone
not necessarily those of the Commission
and its staff so like every other IT

the SEC is also seeing a number of
fundamental changes in technology the
increase in volume and complexity of the
data that we're being asked to or
require to ingest these days is
increasing and at unprecedented rates
also the rapid change in technology and
the technologies that the market is
using is also something that is shifting
very Chik very quickly these days and
then lastly human capital trying to
retain skillsets that will help us
through this transition has also been a
shift at the Commission so in terms of
volumes of data just by example we see
our website sees over 40 million
searches annually we intake 30 billion
trade data trade data transactions a day
through the markets we're storing over
20 petabytes of that data in the cloud
today also the innovation that the
industry you
is changing so we see high-speed trading
now representing over 55% of the US
equity markets we also expect over the
next two years for over two trillion
dollars worth of trade being managed to
Robo advisors and then there's also
increase in online crowdfunding and
peer-to-peer programs now in terms of
human capital the SEC employs about
4,500 federal employees a subset of that
is 20 highly specialized quantitative
and analyst teams to do data analytics
on a lot of the data that we ingest and
just to give you some idea of the volume
seventy four million dollars an annual
trade of securities trading and over 27
thousand registered market participants
are under the oversight of the SEC today
so what did we do to deal with some of
the challenges related to technology we
did what most people did we modernized
our infrastructure we virtualized
servers we consolidated data centers we
did a lot of business process
reengineering to automate our processes
and digitized the way that we were doing
work we also built enterprise level
platforms like our enterprise data
warehouse so that we Confederate the
work across the agency but what we found
was even through all of this work it
wasn't enough to meet the demands of the
challenges of the big data that was
coming into the Commission two quick
examples of that is in 2012 so when a
company Falls to go public they have to
file a form on SEC gov in 2012 Facebook
decided they were going to go public
their initial IPO was posted in February
of 2012 that posting bought SEC gov two
Paul so we quickly had to engineer a
solution to deal with scalability in
those instances so we moved to a
cloud-based content delivery service and
we also moved all our public filings to
the AWS cloud for search capability
likewise we had a situation in 2010 when
we had to flash crash and May and a part
of the SCC's job is if there is a market
event we have to reconstruct the trading
activity so that we can analyze what
happened in the market during the flash
crash in 2010 it took the SEC months to
ingest all the data and do the analytics
on the data so chorus as investors in
American public want answers to market
events and what caused the market events
and you know in a much more timely
manner than months so we worked we
partner with Amazon and we built our
market information data analytics system
which we call Midas and the AWS cloud
today that is more than 20 petabytes of
data but what does Midas system allows
us to do in the cloud is ingest over 30
billion data exchanges a day and we can
analyze the market in near real-time so
what's next for the SEC so we want to
continue down this path of empowering
analytics and innovation so we want to
do more so we've seen the benefits of
security and performance and delivery
from the cloud but now we kind of want
to move to the next generation so we
want to do more with big data and data
analytics we want to do more with
artificial intelligence and machine
learning and then we want to do more in
our development environments so one of
the challenges I've talked about early
on was the human capital challenge and
being able to attract the skillsets and
retain them on government salaries to do
the work that we need to be done at the
SEC so in May
of 2018 we launched our data science
workstations in the Amazon Cloud and
these are state-of-the-art computing
environments with all cutting edge and
oolitic stools which will allow our
quant teams to go in and analyze data at
speeds and volumes that we've never seen
before so one of the issues that we
believe that we can address is this
human capital issue because we believe
if we build these innovative
environments we can attract the skill
set that we need and retain that skill
set because we can push and drive
innovation through these solutions and
we believe that this is the innovation
that will not only get the Securities
and Exchange Commission through the
digital transformation that we're
getting through now but it will also
drive the innovation that we need in the
future so that we can I serve the
ambassador and the American public
better and we can do a better job at
